questions.question_text: Which attribute is responsible for de-duplication?
If more than one alert management rule applies to a particular alert, which of the rules will run based upon the Order of execution field?

choices.A: Only the alert management rule with the highest Order of execution number will run.
choices.C: All alert management rules will run, from the lowest to the highest Order of execution numbers.
choices.B: Only the alert management rule with the lowest Order of execution number will run.
choices.D: All alert management rules will run, from the highest to the lowest Order of execution numbers.

discussion.content:
This questions is outdated, given Alert Management Rule has a field "Multiple alert rules", which define whether to execute other matching Alert Management Rule.
If happen to have this question, well the best is C, as default value of above field during Alert Management Rule creation is set to "Search for additional rules"
C. All alert management rules will run, from the lowest to the highest Order of execution numbers.

questions.question_text: Alerts are processed using which of the following? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
ACD are correct

questions.question_text: The individual commands that the Agent Client Collector executes on the host are known as what? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABE
ABE are correct
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/washingtondc-it-operations-management/page/product/agent-client-collector/concept/checks-policies.html

questions.question_text: What is Event Management licensing based on?

choices.D: The number of CIs in the CMDB that it will be monitoring
choices.C: The number of connectors it will collect data from
choices.A: The number of unique nodes that can send events to the instance
choices.B: The number of connectors and listeners it will collect data from

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Your node count is based on the amount of infrastructure (servers for example) that will be sending events.

Answer is D
The Event Management - Node Count Store job calculates the number of unique nodes that send event information, either directly or through third-parties, to Event Management and are eligible for licensing in the last year. The information from this job is stored in the License Usage [em_unique_nodes] table for visibility by all users. CIs bound to alerts are counted towards licensing; if there are no CIs that are bound to alerts, the event node field is used. Node is a reference to a server, not the instances of the software on it. Your node count is based on the amount of infrastructure (servers for example) that will be sending events.

https://www.servicenow.com/docs/bundle/xanadu-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/task/license-usage.html

Selected Answer: A
D is wrong. The unique number of nodes counts into the license of event management.

comments.content: Correct, now in xanadu release it is a new job in an own license application build by ServiceNow

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
D is wrong. Only the CIs bound to alerts in the last year are calculated for licensing. It does NOT count the # of CIs being monitored in the CMDB. 
"The Event Management - Node Count job calculates the number of unique nodes that send event information, either directly or through third-parties, to Event Management and are eligible for licensing in the last year"

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-it-operations-management/page/product/event-management/task/license-usage.html
